As a devout 'single player games will always be better than online multiplayer ones' kind of guy, I gotta say, Mecha Break is pretty fun.

In terms of moment-to-moment gameplay, Mecha Break is really fun. Fast combat, snappy controls, and there's actually quite a bit of variety in the mechs, to the point that I can't say any of the current lineup is any similar to any other ones. You've got the drill-spear mech, the stealth sniper mech, the [i]air[/i] sniper mech, the absolute tank mech, plane mech, heal mech, the list goes on. I want to say that some could use a bit of tuning (looking at you Welkin), but it's possible that I just suck at certain matchups. The mechs and moment-to-moment gameplay carries the whole game, I think. Because outside of that, I wouldn't say Mecha Break sets any standards.

For the content, I admit I'm not sure I can be a proper judge for it, because I usually hate multiplayer online PvP games and am not very familiar with them, but by itself, Mecha Break feels a tad lacking. You've got the default 6v6 mode with several different types of missions, you've got the 3v3 arena that's basically just a Deathmatch mission from the 6v6 mode, and you've got the extraction shooter mode that seems to have hardly any players and also seems to be the only feasible way to earn any amount of the premium currency as an F2P, because you can sell your loot in the in-game marketplace and pray to the mech gods that someone will buy.

That's also my main criticism, I suppose: there's hardly any way for F2P to earn premium currency; not even a pittance. Most cosmetics, notably outfits, can only be bought with premium currency too, so as someone who loves cosmetic options in games, I can only ask the mech gods why.

Back to the game modes, specifically the ranked 6v6 one. It is ranked, and you get rewards at the end of every season. The rewards? Lootboxes. Yeah, grind your weekend away, place well, and you get a [i]chance[/i] of rolling...something. Is this the standard for online PvP games? I wouldn't know, but if it is, good lord. I'm not even sure what significant thing you can get out of the lootboxes. Most I've gotten out of them are paltry amounts of seasonal points and dupes upon dupes of paintjobs for the mechs that I'll never use because I already have a favourite--and also most of them look like old carpet.

The seasonal points are used as currency, by the way; you use them to buy newly-released mechs (not the default lineup; those are free), items for the extraction mode, and that's about it. There are cosmetics that you can buy with them, but they're locked behind the premium pass. Yeah, you need to spend money to get the privilege to spend in-game money.

And that's about it, I suppose. Good gameplay, everything else is ehhhhhhhhhhhhhhh. I've been picking it up from time to time since launch, and while I enjoy my short bursts of mech on mech action, there isn't really much incentive to keep playing. Still, I recommend at least to check it out, if not only for the mechs and gameplay.

[h2] Mecha BREAK - Review [/h2]

[i]Let me begin with a warning for new players. Pick the time you start this game very carefully.
This game has some of the biggest BS unlock requirements for Season Content and is very, very sparse on the most basic information, like, for example, how long the season is going to last.

Furthermore, you might end up wasting your time farming for something and losing both money and in-game currency because they somehow decide to release a new season on a completely different day than the weekly reset happens, and the day you find out is actually when you try to log in, but they are already mid-maintenance, because you thought the time (the only time!) they showed in their news post was not 8 hours ahead of you. (I know that's partically my fault, but still).

This game has some great gameplay and attention to detail. It can be very immersive.
But god, I don't feel safe investing anything into it because I don't know if my time and money have any value to the developer. I feel robbed.[/i]

Unto the actual review. 

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]

Mecha BREAK offers surprisingly deep character creation and an immersive base to explore, complete with interactable objects and an hangar that shows future Mechs being build in realtime. The game features a mix of PvE and PvP modes. Operation Storm (PvPvE) has fun ideas with free roaming, collecting upgrades, and exploring the map, but it loses purpose once everything is collected, and finding cooperative teammates can be difficult. Covert Operations (PvE Version of Operation Storm) is limited to 3 free weekly attempts. Doing more will cost money. 

On the PvP side, Operation Verge provides classic 6v6 multiplayer with rotating maps and objectives such as capture the flag, point control, and team deathmatch. For smaller and more focused combat, Ace Arena offers fast-paced 3v3 deathmatches that emphasize mech control and coordination. Despite some structural issues, the core mech combat remains enjoyable and is the strongest element of the game.

Matchmaking often fills lobbies with bots, which speeds up queues but creates inconsistent gameplay.

[h3]Monetization[/h3]

Mecha BREAK includes a cash shop, battle pass, and cosmetic bundles. Most prices are reasonable, though some high-end cosmetics, especially full pilot and mech sets, can be very expensive. Ace Recruitment allows players to buy special pilot and mech combos directly for real money, but these are still purely cosmetic versions of mechs obtainable through gameplay.

Players can earn premium currency by selling items on the Matrix Market, although creating a listing sometimes requires spending a small amount of that same currency. The season shop is less friendly to newcomers because of weekly soft caps for earning Mission Tokens and unlock requirements that slow progress toward seasonal rewards.

The game also relies heavily on time-limited seasonal content that disappears once a season ends. This creates a constant pressure to grind before rewards vanish, and it personally makes me hesitant to invest time or money in the game.

[h3]Performance[/h3]

Performance is inconsistent. Mech gameplay generally runs better, but the base area, can perform poorly. The game supports very high graphical settings, yet optimization varies significantly between environments. Lowering rendering quality helps performance but severely impacts visual clarity, making it an unattractive option for players who value image quality. Overall, the game looks good at maximum settings, but currently demands strong hardware and better optimization.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

Overall, Mecha BREAK has a lot of impressive and unique features, from the insane character creation to the immersive base and hangar systems. The gameplay is fun and varied, but there are clear drawbacks, like performance issues, unlock requirements in the season shop, and the limited Covert Operations. Monetization is mostly fair for a free-to-play game, though some cosmetic options feel overpriced. Despite its flaws, I am still having fun and will probably keep playing for the time being. It‚Äôs far from perfect, but there‚Äôs enough here to make it worth trying if you enjoy mech combat and good character customization.

In many ways I think Mecha Break proves that the mecha combat genre doesn't really have the legs to be a big PvP contender. It asks too much of your time while competing with the likes of Marvel Rivals and whatever BLOPS, PUBG, BFUS, GGGR, or Forknife that gets all the attention. The game is hemorrhaging players tired of slapfighting each other in the same 5 pvp modes on the same 9 maps.  Most remaining interested players would rather play covert operations against bots at their own place than sweat out an extraction royale or team deathmatch.

The new releases, while high quality, are not remotely abundant enough to support this live service model.  There is a severe quality-to-content output bottleneck that is hampering this game's entire market, culminating in the removal of the in-game player auction house.  Seasun really removed the only mechanism within this game that actually generated value over time, a very fatal shot in their own foot.

Mecha Break still has a bunch of dedicated mecha [strike]idiots[/strike] fans like myself who would actually keep paying their asking price for a reason to grind beyond player adversity.  If we had another context in which to see our Strikers and Pilots beyond endgame victory or defeat screens, we would inhabit this game much more.

The maps are boring and empty, and the absence of destructible elements means the gigantic power of your machine is never truly felt. In fact, the gap between what the Mecha is supposed to be and the in-game feeling is immense, a fact made starkly clear when seeing the Mecha at real scale in the base. My exploration of other modes was equally futile, as Mashmak felt uninteresting and empty.

Despite these warnings, I pushed towards competition. I played about fifteen hours in Quick Match before managing to figure out how to launch ranked because the disgusting menus made me reluctant to search for anything. Once in ranked, the game collapsed. The technical problem was immediate: the ping is a constant 50ms (the servers are at fault). I reached Master rank in just 20 hours of ranked play, which is extremely fast because the matches were too easy (likely filled with bots). Once at the top, the game stops finding matches; I waited up to an hour with no success. The balance is disastrous: in my opinion, Aquila and Welkin are far too powerful, and Falcon and Luminae are useless. Furthermore, simple modes are flawed, like the 8-kill setting where you literally spawn on the opposing team.

Finally, these long waits allowed me to discover the deep sense of unease linked to the developers' priorities. The camera's plunging view of the pilot's silhouette at the start of every match is awkward. By searching Google for the purpose of areas like the gym, I discovered the photo mode and felt soiled. You cannot market a game as a future eSport title when the energy is spent on this superficial and awkward content rather than stable servers.

In conclusion, the only positive thing I find about Mecha Break is that it highlights the quality of other Mecha games. I cannot recommend this game.

Pros:
- The controls and combat are (mostly) extremely solid and fun.
- Mech designs are familiar and reliable, albeit a bit "safe" in visual design. Could be more abstract or bizarre in some cases.
- I was surprised that the system resources and performance wasn't an issue. I've got an impressive, self-built PC but I was expecting more nonsense with hardware.

Neutral:

- Monetization is a big aggressive. They should be focused on attracting new players, not pricing out the ones that are there. - No PvE mode. That's criminal in this. I have zero interest in PvP games at all.
- Customizable loadouts for the PvPvE game mode are stupid.
